parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the post.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>False. The post does not refer to any specific parliamentary candidate by name, surname, or party affiliation.  While it encourages voting, it doesn't endorse any particular candidate or party.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. This is a paid Facebook post, inherently designed to reach a wide audience. The message is general and not directed at specific individuals.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>False. The primary objective of the post seems to be civic engagement—encouraging people to vote. While this indirectly benefits all candidates, the post itself lacks any explicit endorsement or attempt to sway votes towards a specific candidate or party. The message is framed as a general call to action, not a partisan appeal.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>Partially True. The post could be considered a form of citizen journalism, aiming to promote civic participation. However, it strays from strict journalistic neutrality by implicitly encouraging voting, even if not for a specific candidate.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>False. The post doesn't express a personal opinion; rather, it promotes a civic duty.  The statement "Nu, nu intrăm în politică" further reinforces the intention to remain neutral regarding specific political entities.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>919869826755185</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The Facebook post promotes civic engagement by encouraging voting on Romania's National Day, which coincides with elections.  While the post's intent is to encourage participation in the democratic process, it does not explicitly endorse any particular candidate or party.  The phrasing "Nu, nu intrăm în politică" suggests an attempt to avoid partisan campaigning.  The post's broad reach and paid nature are characteristics of electoral propaganda, but the lack of specific candidate endorsement weakens the case for a violation.  The "in dubio pro reo" principle should be applied here.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates/>
<responsible-party-or-group>Salt Bank</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police/>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
